abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            overall, however the project is unsustainable because of
            these factors: The validity of the participatory and
            progressive approach is questionable for larger-scale
            schemes; environmental sustainability was compromised by
            including large-scale schemes; the allocation of project
            funds to locust control; the occurrence of cyclones in 1999;
            the absence of a time frame for the intervention, and the
            subsequent perpetuation of project assistance to water
            users' associations; long delays in official operations
            and maintenance (O&M) transfer and land registration
            because of the lack of involvement of the Land Ministry; and
            the weak level of upfront contribution and O&M costs.
            Both World Bank and Borrower performances were rated as
            marginally satisfactory. Some lessons learned were: Even
            modest investments can create momentum for management
            transfer if they include proper mobilization and training of
            farmers. The project approach used should be consistent
            witht the selected disbursement approach. The participatory
            approach should be well-structured with an agreed agenda and
            objectives among all stakeholders. Irrigation projects
            should be part of a multi-sectoral approach, integrated into
            watersheds management programs and including land tenure,
            credit, transport, access to marketing, input supply, and
            extension. Farmers should adopt intensified irrigation
            rigorously, use high-yielding varieties, double cropping,
            and fertilizers.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Irrigation Rehabilitation
            Project will support the country development strategy on
            four fronts: (a) Promoting growth. It will contribute to
            increased agricultural output through better water
            management and intensified agricultural extension. (b)
            Poverty reduction. It will contribute to improved rural
            incomes and food security by improving production and
            productivity on irrigation schemes country-wide. (c)
            Improving environmental management. It will develop
            techniques for environmental assessment of irrigation
            rehabilitation and reinforce local capacity. This project
            will also establish operational procedures for the transfer
            of management of the operation and maintenance of public
            irrigation schemes to water users and thus will serve to
            reduce the burden of public expenditure on the maintenance
            of such irrigation infrastructure. It will provide the means
            for more efficient management of the decentralized services
            of the Ministry of Agriculture in agricultural extension,
            rural works supervision and local planning and programming.
